thread.title: With Jonathan Bullard back, Gators defensive line showing some bite
thread.title_full: With Jonathan Bullard back, Gators defensive line showing some bite

author: Graham Hack
title: With Jonathan Bullard back, Gators defensive line showing some bite
text:
With Jonathan Bullard back, Gators defensive line showing some bite 
By Graham Hack Wed, Sep 30, 2015 @ 10:49 pm | updated Wed, Sep 30, 2015 @ 10:56 pm Back Photo: 1 of 3 Next AP East Carolina running back Chris Hairston (22) carries past Florida defensive lineman Jonathan Bullard (90) during the first half of an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Sept. 12, 2015, in Gainesville, Fla. Back Photo: 2 of 3 Next AP Florida defensive lineman Jonathan Bullard raises his arms to get some crowd noise during a Sept. 12 game against East Carolina. John Raoux Associated Press Back Photo: 3 of 3 Next AP David Stephenson Associated Press Florida defensive linemen Alex McCalister (left) and Jonathan Bullard celebrate after Bullard sacked Kentucky quarterback Patrick Towles during a game on Sept. 19. 
If he had wanted, Jonathan Bullard could be playing in the NFL right now. 
He was slated to be drafted in the 2014 NFL Draft, but he wasn’t projected to go as high as he had hoped. 
So instead, the UF defensive lineman decided to come back to school to help improve his stock and become a first-round pick. 
So far, so good. 
Through four games, Bullard has 21 tackles, eight of which are for loss — good for a tie for fifth nationally — and four sacks, putting him in a tie for 13th nationally. 
In his entire junior season, he racked up 2.5 sacks and 8.5 tackles for loss. 
His play this season has caught the eye of former LSU All-American defensive lineman Marcus Spears, who believes the senior has a good chance to achieve first-round status. 
“I think Bullard is a monster,” Spears said while part of the “SEC Nation” stop in Gainesville last weekend. “Every year, you’ve got guys in the conference who can change the game up front. He’s definitely that guy. He’ll be a Day 1 pick. Potentially first round. Big, athletic kid. D-linemen don’t just fall off trees, man. So when you find someone that athletic with long arms and range, he’s a scout’s dream. He’s a guy you can put up on the board, and everybody in the organization will agree that he can make a difference.” 
Bullard is also making a difference for Florida’s entire defensive line, too. 
Although Ole Miss’ defensive line is grabbing headlines leading into Saturday’s matchup with Florida, it’s the Gators’ line that has consistently gotten to the quarterback in 2015. 
UF ranks in a tie for sixth in the nation with 14 sacks this year, and the Rebels’ highly touted pass rush has managed three this season, good for 118th nationally. 
Part of that is from Bullard’s performance, but it’s also the way he affects his teammates. 
Before Bullard decided to come back, first-year Gators coach Jim McElwain was faced with the prospect of an inexperienced defensive line that had no proven playmakers. 
So to say he was happy to have the senior back would be an understatement. 
“I can’t tell you how glad I am that he chose to come back,” McElwain said. “Through consistent play, [he] is helping himself every time he’s out there. He’s been a great leader. He’s been a guy that I think has really grabbed that D-line group and has affected some guys in a real positive way.”
